[Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston was [[Mr. Bart]137-mr. bart ’s widowed sister]695-mr. bart ’s widowed sister , and if [she]114-mrs. peniston was by no means [the richest of [the family group]697-the family group]696-the richest of the family group , [[its]697-the family group other members]698-its other members nevertheless abounded in reasons why [she]114-mrs. peniston was clearly destined by [Providence]141-providence to assume the charge of [Lily]109-lily . In the first place [she]114-mrs. peniston was alone , and it would be charming for [her]114-mrs. peniston to have [a young companion]699-a young companion . Then [she]114-mrs. peniston sometimes travelled , and [Lily]109-lily ’s familiarity with foreign customs — deplored as a misfortune by [[her]109-lily more conservative relatives]700-her more conservative relatives — would at least enable [her]109-lily to act as [a kind of courier]701-a kind of courier . But as a matter of fact [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston had not been affected by these considerations . [She]114-mrs. peniston had taken [the girl]665-the girl simply because [no one else]703-no one else would have [her]665-the girl , and because [she]114-mrs. peniston had the kind of moral MAUVAISE HONTE which makes the public display of selfishness difficult , though it does not interfere with its private indulgence . It would have been impossible for [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston to be heroic on [a desert island]704-a desert island , but with the eyes of [[her]114-mrs. peniston little world]705-her little world upon [her]114-mrs. peniston [she]114-mrs. peniston took a certain pleasure in [her]114-mrs. peniston act . [She]114-mrs. peniston reaped the reward to which disinterestedness is entitled , and found [an agreeable companion in [[her]114-mrs. peniston niece]707-her niece]706-an agreeable companion in her niece . [She]114-mrs. peniston had expected to find [Lily]109-lily headstrong , critical and “ foreign”—for[109-lily] even [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston , though [she]114-mrs. peniston occasionally went abroad , had [the family]599-the family dread of foreignness — but [the girl]665-the girl showed a pliancy , which , to a more penetrating mind than [[her]665-the girl aunt]345-her aunt ’s , might have been less reassuring than the open selfishness of youth . Misfortune had made [Lily]109-lily supple instead of hardening [her]109-lily , and a pliable substance is less easy to break than a stiff one . [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston , however , did not suffer from [[her]114-mrs. peniston niece]707-her niece ’s adaptability . [Lily]109-lily had no intention of taking advantage of [[her]109-lily aunt]345-her aunt ’s good - nature . [She]109-lily was in truth grateful for the refuge offered [her]109-lily : [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston ’s opulent interior was at least not externally dingy . But dinginess is a quality which assumes all manner of disguises ; and [Lily]109-lily soon found that it was as latent in the expensive routine of [[her]109-lily aunt]345-her aunt ’s life as in the makeshift existence of a continental pension . [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston was one of [the episodical persons who form the padding of life]714-the episodical persons who form the padding of life . It was impossible to believe that [she]114-mrs. peniston had [herself]114-mrs. peniston ever been a focus of activities . The most vivid thing about [her]114-mrs. peniston was the fact that [[her]109-lily grandmother]715-her grandmother had been [a Van Alstyne]142-cornelia van alstyne . This connection with the well - fed and industrious stock of early [New York]6-new york revealed itself in the glacial neatness of [[Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston ’s drawing - room]716-mrs. peniston ’s drawing - room and in the excellence of [her]114-mrs. peniston cuisine . [She]114-mrs. peniston belonged to [the class of old New Yorkers who have always lived well , dressed expensively , and done little else]717-the class of old new yorkers who have always lived well , dressed expensively , and done little else ; and to these inherited obligations [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston faithfully conformed . [She]114-mrs. peniston had always been [a looker - on at life]718-a looker - on at life , and [her]114-mrs. peniston mind resembled one of those little mirrors which [[her]114-mrs. peniston Dutch ancestors]719-her dutch ancestors were accustomed to affix to [their]719-her dutch ancestors upper windows , so that from the depths of an impenetrable domesticity [they]719-her dutch ancestors might see what was happening in [the street]310-the street . [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston was [the owner of [a country - place in [New Jersey]26-new jersey]722-a country - place in new jersey]721-the owner of a country - place in new jersey , but [she]114-mrs. peniston had never lived [there]2755-there since [[her]114-mrs. peniston husband]609-her husband ’s death — a remote event , which appeared to dwell in [her]114-mrs. peniston memory chiefly as a dividing point in the personal reminiscences that formed the staple of [her]114-mrs. peniston conversation . [She]114-mrs. peniston was [a woman who remembered dates with intensity]725-a woman who remembered dates with intensity , and could tell at a moment ’s notice whether the drawing - room curtains had been renewed before or after [Mr. Peniston]143-mr. peniston ’s last illness . [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston thought [the country]304-the country lonely and trees damp , and cherished a vague fear of meeting [a bull]727-a bull . To guard against such contingencies [she]114-mrs. peniston frequented [the more populous watering - places]728-the more populous watering - places , where [she]114-mrs. peniston installed [herself]114-mrs. peniston impersonally in [a hired house]729-a hired house and looked on at life through the matting screen of [[her]114-mrs. peniston verandah]730-her verandah . In the care of [such a guardian]731-such a guardian , it soon became clear to [Lily]109-lily that [she]109-lily was to enjoy only the material advantages of good food and expensive clothing ; and , though far from underrating these , [she]109-lily would gladly have exchanged them for what [Mrs. Bart]136-mrs. bart had taught [her]109-lily to regard as opportunities . [She]109-lily sighed to think what [[her]109-lily mother]569-her mother ’s fierce energies would have accomplished , had they been coupled with [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston ’s resources . [Lily]109-lily had abundant energy of [her]109-lily own , but it was restricted by the necessity of adapting [herself]109-lily to [[her]109-lily aunt]345-her aunt ’s habits . [She]109-lily saw that at all costs [she]109-lily must keep [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston ’s favour till , as [Mrs. Bart]136-mrs. bart would have phrased it , [she]109-lily could stand on [her]109-lily own legs . [Lily]109-lily had no mind for the vagabond life of [the poor relation]734-the poor relation , and to adapt [herself]109-lily to [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston [she]109-lily had , to some degree , to assume [that lady]486-that lady ’s passive attitude . [She]109-lily had fancied at first that it would be easy to draw [[her]109-lily aunt]345-her aunt into the whirl of [her]109-lily own activities , but there was a static force in [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston against which [[her]114-mrs. peniston niece]707-her niece ’s efforts spent themselves in vain . To attempt to bring [her]109-lily into active relation with life was like tugging at a piece of furniture which has been screwed to the floor . [She]114-mrs. peniston did not , indeed , expect [Lily]109-lily to remain equally immovable : [she]109-lily had all the American guardian ’s indulgence for the volatility of youth . [She]109-lily had indulgence also for certain other habits of [[her]114-mrs. peniston niece]707-her niece ’s . It seemed to [her]109-lily natural that [Lily]109-lily should spend all [her]109-lily money on dress , and [she]109-lily supplemented [the girl]665-the girl ’s scanty income by occasional “ handsome presents ”[109-lily] meant to be applied to the same purpose . [Lily]109-lily , who was intensely practical , would have preferred a fixed allowance ; but [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston liked the periodical recurrence of gratitude evoked by unexpected cheques , and was perhaps shrewd enough to perceive that such a method of giving kept alive in [[her]114-mrs. peniston niece]707-her niece a salutary sense of dependence . Beyond this , [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston had not felt called upon to do anything for [her]114-mrs. peniston charge : [she]114-mrs. peniston had simply stood aside and let [her]109-lily take [the field]741-the field . [Lily]109-lily had taken it , at first with the confidence of assured possessorship , then with gradually narrowing demands , till now [she]109-lily found [herself]109-lily actually struggling for a foothold on the broad space which had once seemed [her]109-lily own for the asking . How it happened [she]109-lily did not yet know . Sometimes [she]109-lily thought it was because [Mrs. Peniston]114-mrs. peniston had been too passive , and again [she]109-lily feared it was because [she]109-lily [herself]109-lily had not been passive enough . Had [she]109-lily shown an undue eagerness for victory ? Had [she]109-lily lacked patience , pliancy and dissimulation ? Whether [she]109-lily charged [herself]109-lily with these faults or absolved [herself]109-lily from them , made no difference in the sum - total of [her]109-lily failure . [Younger and plainer girls]742-younger and plainer girls had been married off by dozens , and [she]109-lily was nine - and - twenty , and still [Miss Bart]109-lily . [She]109-lily was beginning to have fits of angry rebellion against fate , when [she]109-lily longed to drop out of the race and make an independent life for [herself]109-lily . But what manner of life would it be ? [She]109-lily had barely enough money to pay [[her]109-lily dress - makers]743-her dress - makers ’ bills and [her]109-lily gambling debts ; and none of the desultory interests which [she]109-lily dignified with the name of tastes was pronounced enough to enable [her]109-lily to live contentedly in obscurity . Ah , no — [she]109-lily was too intelligent not to be honest with [herself]109-lily . [She]109-lily knew that [she]109-lily hated dinginess as much as [[her]109-lily mother]569-her mother had hated it , and to [her]109-lily last breath [she]109-lily meant to fight against it , dragging [herself]109-lily up again and again above its flood till [she]109-lily gained the bright pinnacles of success which presented such a slippery surface to [her]109-lily clutch . Chapter 4 The next morning , on [her]109-lily breakfast tray , [Miss Bart]109-lily found a note from [[her]109-lily hostess]745-her hostess . “ Dearest [Lily]109-lily , ”[745-her hostess] it ran , “ if it is not too much of a bore to be down by ten , will [you]109-lily come to [[my]745-her hostess sitting - room]2879-my sitting - room to help [me]745-her hostess with some tiresome things ? ”[745-her hostess] [Lily]109-lily tossed aside the note and subsided on [her]109-lily pillows with a sigh . It WAS a bore to be down by ten — an hour regarded at [Bellomont]3-bellomont as vaguely synchronous with sunrise — and [she]109-lily knew too well the nature of the tiresome things in question . [Miss Pragg]144-miss pragg , [the secretary]746-the secretary , had been called away , and there would be notes and dinner - cards to write , lost addresses to hunt up , and other social drudgery to perform . It was understood that [Miss Bart]109-lily should fill the gap in such emergencies , and [she]109-lily usually recognized the obligation without a murmur . Today , however , it renewed the sense of servitude which the previous night ’s review of [her]109-lily cheque - book had produced . Everything in [her]109-lily surroundings ministered to feelings of ease and amenity . The windows stood open to the sparkling freshness of the September morning , and between the yellow boughs [she]109-lily caught a perspective of hedges and parterres leading by degrees of lessening formality to the free undulations of [the park]747-the park . [[Her]109-lily maid]565-her maid had kindled a little fire on the hearth , and it contended cheerfully with the sunlight which slanted across the moss - green carpet and caressed the curved sides of an old marquetry desk . Near the bed stood a table holding [her]109-lily breakfast tray , with its harmonious porcelain and silver , a handful of violets in a slender glass , and the morning paper folded beneath [her]109-lily letters . There was nothing new to [Lily]109-lily in these tokens of a studied luxury ; but , though they formed a part of [her]109-lily atmosphere , [she]109-lily never lost [her]109-lily sensitiveness to their charm . Mere display left [her]109-lily with a sense of superior distinction ; but [she]109-lily felt an affinity to all the subtler manifestations of wealth . [Mrs. Trenor]123-mrs. trenor ’s summons , however , suddenly recalled [her]109-lily state of dependence , and [she]109-lily rose and dressed in a mood of irritability that [she]109-lily was usually too prudent to indulge . [She]109-lily knew that such emotions leave lines on the face as well as in the character , and [she]109-lily had meant to take warning by the little creases which [her]109-lily midnight survey had revealed . The matter of course tone of [Mrs. Trenor]123-mrs. trenor ’s greeting deepened [her]109-lily irritation . If one did drag [one]2737-one ’s self out of bed at such an hour , and come down fresh and radiant to the monotony of note - writing , some special recognition of the sacrifice seemed fitting . But [Mrs. Trenor]123-mrs. trenor ’s tone showed no consciousness of the fact . “ Oh , [Lily]109-lily , that ’s nice of [you]109-lily , ”[123-mrs. trenor] [she]123-mrs. trenor merely sighed across the chaos of letters , bills and other domestic documents which gave an incongruously commercial touch to the slender elegance of [her]123-mrs. trenor writing - table . “ There are such lots of horrors this morning , ”[123-mrs. trenor] [she]123-mrs. trenor added , clearing a space in the centre of the confusion and rising to yield [her]123-mrs. trenor seat to [Miss Bart]109-lily . [Mrs. Trenor]123-mrs. trenor was [a tall fair woman]750-a tall fair woman , whose height just saved [her]123-mrs. trenor from redundancy . [Her]123-mrs. trenor rosy blondness had survived some forty years of futile activity without showing much trace of ill - usage except in a diminished play of feature . It was difficult to define [her]123-mrs. trenor beyond saying that [she]123-mrs. trenor seemed to exist only as [a hostess]751-a hostess , not so much from any exaggerated instinct of hospitality as because [she]123-mrs. trenor could not sustain life except in a crowd . The collective nature of [her]123-mrs. trenor interests exempted [her]123-mrs. trenor from the ordinary rivalries of [her]123-mrs. trenor sex , and [she]123-mrs. trenor knew no more personal emotion than that of hatred for [the woman who presumed to give bigger dinners or have more amusing house - parties than [herself]123-mrs. trenor]752-the woman who presumed to give bigger dinners or have more amusing house - parties than herself . As [her]123-mrs. trenor social talents , backed by [Mr. Trenor]145-mr. trenor ’s bank - account , almost always assured [her]123-mrs. trenor ultimate triumph in such competitions , success had developed in [her]123-mrs. trenor an unscrupulous good nature toward the rest of [her]123-mrs. trenor sex , and in [Miss Bart]109-lily ’s utilitarian classification of [[her]123-mrs. trenor friends]406-her friends , [Mrs. Trenor]123-mrs. trenor ranked as [the woman who was least likely to “ go back ”]2880-the woman who was least likely to “ go back ”[123-mrs. trenor] on [her]123-mrs. trenor . “ It was simply inhuman of [Pragg]144-miss pragg to go off now , ”[123-mrs. trenor] [Mrs. Trenor]123-mrs. trenor declared , as [[her]123-mrs. trenor friend]754-her friend seated [herself]754-her friend at the desk . “ [She]109-lily says [[her]109-lily sister]2881-her sister is going to have [a baby]2882-a baby — as if that were anything to having a house - party ! [I]123-mrs. trenor ’m sure [I]123-mrs. trenor shall get most horribly mixed up and there will be some awful rows . When [I]123-mrs. trenor was down at [Tuxedo]1-tuxedo [I]123-mrs. trenor asked a lot of [people]2804-people for next week , and [I]123-mrs. trenor ’ve mislaid the list and ca n’t remember who is coming . And this week is going to be a horrid failure too — and [Gwen Van Osburgh]119-gwen will go back and tell [[her]119-gwen mother]569-her mother how bored [people]2804-people were . [I]123-mrs. trenor did mean to ask [the Wetheralls]120-the wetheralls — that was a blunder of [[Gus]111-gus ’s]2886-gus ’s . [They]120-the wetheralls disapprove of [Carry Fisher]146-carry fisher , [you]2887-you know . As if [one]2737-one could help having [Carry Fisher]146-carry fisher ! And [poor Carry]146-carry fisher has to consider every dollar . [Some one]2889-some one said the other day that there was a divorce and a case of appendicitis in [every family one]2890-every family one knows . Besides , [Carry]146-carry fisher is [the only person who can keep [Gus]111-gus in a good humour when [we]2892-we have bores in [the house]488-the house]2891-the only person who can keep gus in a good humour when we have bores in the house . Do [you]109-lily mean to say [you]109-lily ’ve actually done it ? ”[123-mrs. trenor] [Miss Bart]109-lily smiled . “ [I]109-lily only mean to say that [Mr. Gryce]127-mr. gryce and [I]109-lily are getting to be [very good friends]2945-very good friends . ”[109-lily] “ H’m — [I]123-mrs. trenor see . ”[123-mrs. trenor] [Mrs. Trenor]123-mrs. trenor fixed a rapt eye upon [her]109-lily . “ [You]109-lily know [they]2946-they say [he]127-mr. gryce has eight hundred thousand a year — and spends nothing , except on some rubbishy old books . And [[his]127-mr. gryce mother]2809-his mother has heart - disease and will leave [him]127-mr. gryce a lot more . OH , [LILY]109-lily , DO GO SLOWLY , ”[123-mrs. trenor] [[her]109-lily friend]754-her friend adjured [her]109-lily . [Miss Bart]109-lily continued to smile without annoyance . “ [I]109-lily should n’t , for instance , ”[109-lily] [she]109-lily remarked , “ be in any haste to tell [him]127-mr. gryce that [he]127-mr. gryce had a lot of rubbishy old books . ”[109-lily] “ No , of course not ; [I]123-mrs. trenor know [you]109-lily ’re wonderful about getting up [people]2804-people ’s subjects . But [he]127-mr. gryce ’s horribly shy , and easily shocked , and — and — — ”[123-mrs. trenor] “ Why do n’t [you]109-lily say it , [Judy]126-judy ? [I]123-mrs. trenor have the reputation of being on the hunt for [a rich husband]2949-a rich husband ? ”[123-mrs. trenor] “ Oh , [I]123-mrs. trenor do n’t mean that ; [he]127-mr. gryce would n’t believe it of [you]109-lily — at first , ”[123-mrs. trenor] said [Mrs. Trenor]123-mrs. trenor , with candid shrewdness . “ But [you]109-lily know things are rather lively here at times — [I]123-mrs. trenor must give [Jack]125-jack stepney and [Gus]111-gus a hint — and if [he]127-mr. gryce thought [you]109-lily were what [[his]127-mr. gryce mother]2809-his mother would call fast — oh , well , [you]109-lily know what [I]123-mrs. trenor mean . Do n’t wear [your]109-lily scarlet CREPE - DE - CHINE for dinner , and do n’t smoke if [you]109-lily can help it , [[Lily]109-lily dear]2951-lily dear ! ”[123-mrs. trenor] [Lily]109-lily pushed aside [her]109-lily finished work with a dry smile . “ [You]109-lily ’re very kind , [Judy]126-judy : [I]109-lily ’ll lock up [my]109-lily cigarettes and wear that last year ’s dress [you]109-lily sent [me]109-lily this morning . And if [you]109-lily are really interested in [my]109-lily career , perhaps [you]109-lily ’ll be kind enough not to ask [me]109-lily to play bridge again this evening . ”[109-lily] “ [Bridge]158-bridge ? Does [he]2952-he mind bridge , too ? Oh , [Lily]109-lily , what an awful life [you]109-lily ’ll lead !
